Expectation1: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation1: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: I stared at my screen, the code review comments blinking at me like warning lights. “Performance issues in the new feature,” my lead had written. I knew the expectation: clean, maintainable, efficient code. But the clock was ticking, and the feature was almost ready. I could patch it quickly, push it through, and fix it later, but that wasn’t how I wanted to work. My phone buzzed—a reminder to vote today. I’d planned to go during lunch, but I realized I’d left my main ID at home. I had a backup card in my bag, but I wasn’t sure if it would be accepted. I could run home after work to get the right ID, but that would mean staying late to finish the code review fixes. My team was counting on me to deliver quality work, but I also felt the weight of my civic duty. The expectations pressed in from both sides, and I sat frozen, torn between the demands of my profession and my responsibility as a voter, unsure which role to prioritize.
